meta.title: SEBI Grade A Phase 2 - AS 10 (PPE) Forensic Test
meta.description: High-yield technical questions covering Recognition, Measurement, Revaluation Logic, and Depreciation protocols under AS 10.

questions.question:
(Scope & Definitions)
Which of the following biological assets is strictly EXCLUDED from the scope of AS 10 (PPE) and must be treated as Inventory?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer: Maize crops ready for harvest

System Logic: AS 10 applies to Bearer Plants (Tea, Grape, Rubber, Mango) because they are used to produce output > 12 months. However, it explicitly excludes Annual Crops (Maize, Wheat) which are cultivated to be harvested as agricultural produce. These fall under Agriculture/Inventory protocols.

questions.question:
(Cost Recognition Algorithm)
A company installs a new machine. Which of the following costs is a System Defect if capitalized into the carrying amount of the asset?
options: Costs of staff training to operate the machine
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer: Costs of staff training

The Trap: Thinking training is necessary for operation.
Brutal Fact: Training enhances the human resource, not the asset's capability. AS 10 explicitly lists 'Costs of conducting business... including staff training' as an Expense (P&L). It does not add value to the hardware.

questions.question:
(Trial Run Forensics)
Entity X incurs ₹50,000 on a trial run. The samples produced during testing were sold for ₹5,000. How is this processed in the Cost Stack?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer: Debit PPE ₹45,000 (Net Capitalization)

System Logic: Costs of testing are directly attributable. The standard mandates that net proceeds from selling items produced during testing must be Deducted from the Cost of the asset. You do NOT book revenue.

questions.question:
(Revaluation Memory Protocol)
An asset costing ₹100 was previously revalued down to ₹80 (Loss of ₹20 charged to P&L). In the current year, its Fair Value rises to ₹110. How is the ₹30 gain allocated?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer: ₹20 to P&L; ₹10 to Revaluation Surplus

The Logic Gate: The system has 'Memory'. You must first Reverse the Previous Loss charged to P&L (₹20). Only the Excess gain (₹10) is credited to the Revaluation Surplus (Equity).

questions.question:
(Depreciation Trigger)
Machine A is ready for use on Nov 1. Management waits and starts active production on Mar 1. When does the Depreciation algorithm initiate?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer: November 1

The Trap: Confusing 'Usage' with 'Availability'.
Brutal Fact: Depreciation starts when the asset is in the location and condition necessary to be Capable of Operating (Available for Use). Management delay is irrelevant.

questions.question:
(Maintenance vs. Capitalization)
An airline performs a mandatory 'Major Inspection' on an aircraft every 3 years. How is the cost of a new inspection treated if the cost of the previous inspection is unknown?
options: Capitalize new cost; Do not derecognize old cost
Capitalize new cost; Derecognize estimated carrying amount of old inspection
Capitalize only if it extends useful life
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer: Capitalize new cost; Derecognize estimated carrying amount of old inspection

System Constraint: AS 10 mandates that Major Inspections are capitalized. Crucially, any remaining carrying amount of the Previous Inspection must be derecognized. If unknown, use the current cost as a proxy to estimate the old value.

questions.question:
(Change in Method Logic)
A company changes its depreciation method from SLM to WDV. Under AS 10 and AS 5, this is classified as:
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer: Change in Accounting Estimate (Prospective)

The Trap: Calling it a Policy change.
Brutal Fact: Changes in Depreciation Method, Useful Life, or Residual Value are Estimates. You do not restate past years. You apply the new logic to the current carrying amount for future periods.

questions.question:
(Asset Exchange Protocol)
Asset A (Book Value ₹100, Fair Value ₹150) is exchanged for Asset B. The transaction lacks commercial substance. At what value is Asset B recorded?
options: Lower of FV or Book Value
Higher of FV or Book Value
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer: ₹100 (Book Value of Asset Given)

Logic Gate: If the transaction Lacks Commercial Substance (cash flows don't change), the system ignores Fair Value. The new asset takes the Book Value of the old asset. No gain/loss is booked.

questions.question:
(Component Accounting)
A furnace (Cost ₹10Cr) has a lining (Cost ₹2Cr, Life 5 years) and the main body (Cost ₹8Cr, Life 20 years). How must depreciation be calculated?
options: Depreciate ₹2Cr over 5 years and ₹8Cr over 20 years separately
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer: Depreciate ₹2Cr over 5 years and ₹8Cr over 20 years separately

System Rule: Component Accounting is Mandatory when parts have significantly different useful lives. Blended rates are prohibited.

questions.question:
(Revaluation Frequency)
For a class of assets experiencing significant and volatile changes in fair value, AS 10 mandates revaluation:
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer: Annually

System Limit: Volatile assets = Annual Revaluation. Assets with insignificant movements = 3 to 5 years. The goal is to keep Carrying Amount close to Fair Value at the balance sheet date.

questions.question:
(Decommissioning Liability)
The initial estimate of the costs of dismantling and restoring the site (Decommissioning) must be:
options: Included in the Cost of the Asset
Ignored until the cost is actually incurred
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer: Included in the Cost of the Asset

The Formula: Cost = Purchase Price + Attributable Costs + Decommissioning Provision. This obligation is incurred at the start, so it is capitalized and depreciated over the asset's life.

questions.question:
(Spare Parts Classification)
Under AS 10 Revised, spare parts are recognized as PPE if:
options: They meet the definition of PPE (Used > 12 months)
They are used only in connection with a specific asset
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer: They meet the definition of PPE (Used > 12 months)

Forensics: Old standard distinguished between 'standby/spares'. Revised AS 10 has a single logic gate: If it meets the PPE definition (tangible, use > 12m), it is PPE. If not, it is Inventory (AS 2).

questions.question:
(Deferred Payment Math)
An asset is purchased for ₹120 Lakhs on deferred credit (normal cash price is ₹100 Lakhs). If not capitalized under AS 16, how is the ₹20 Lakh difference treated?
options: Recognized as Interest Expense over the credit period
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer: Recognized as Interest Expense over the credit period

System Logic: The asset is recorded at the Cash Price Equivalent (₹100L). The excess (₹20L) is interest financing cost, expensed over time, unless it qualifies as a 'Qualifying Asset' under AS 16.

questions.question:
(Retirement Valuation)
An item of PPE is retired from active use and held for disposal. It must be carried in the Balance Sheet at:
options: Lower of Carrying Amount and Net Realizable Value
Higher of Carrying Amount and Net Realizable Value
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer: Lower of Carrying Amount and Net Realizable Value

System Constraint: Once retired/held for sale, depreciation stops. The asset is treated like inventory: valued at the lower of Book Value or what you can sell it for (NRV). Any write-down is an immediate loss.

questions.question:
(Definition - Admin)
Under AS 10, the term 'Administrative Purposes' is used in a wider sense to include:
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer: Selling and Distribution functions

Technical Definition: AS 10 defines PPE as assets held for production, rental, or administrative purposes. The text clarifies that 'Administrative' includes Selling, Distribution, Finance, and Personnel functions.
